unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities News Snippet: Load Shedding Intensifies Across Southern India**
normalised: Energy and Utilities News Snippet: Load Shedding Intensifies Across Southern India

unnormalised: Chennai, October 26th - Several states in Southern India are facing increased load shedding as demand surges amidst the festive season. Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation (TANGEDCO) announced unscheduled power cuts averaging 2-3 hours daily across various districts, including Madurai and Coimbatore.
normalised: Chennai, October twenty sixth - Several states in Southern India are facing increased load shedding as demand surges amidst the festive season. Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation (T A N G E D C O) announced unscheduled power cuts averaging two to three hours daily across various districts, including Madurai and Coimbatore.

unnormalised: Kerala State Electricity Board (KSEB) officials cited a dip in hydroelectric power generation due to lower than anticipated rainfall as a key factor. The increased demand, partially attributed to preparations for the upcoming Onam celebrations, is further straining the grid. Many households are reportedly using more electricity for lighting and cooking traditional Onam Sadhya.
normalised: Kerala State Electricity Board (K S E B) officials cited a dip in hydroelectric power generation due to lower than anticipated rainfall as a key factor. The increased demand, partially attributed to preparations for the upcoming Onam celebrations, is further straining the grid. Many households are reportedly using more electricity for lighting and cooking traditional Onam Sadhya.

unnormalised: Karnataka Power Transmission Corporation Limited (KPTCL) reports similar challenges. "We are working to optimise distribution and minimize disruption," stated a KPTCL spokesperson. Industry experts warn the situation could worsen in the coming weeks, impacting small businesses and households alike, particularly those reliant on electricity for daily activities like cooking and running water pumps. Residents are advised to conserve energy wherever possible. Reports indicate that the average household power bill could increase by Rs. 500-800 this month due to increased usage and reliance on backup generators.
normalised: Karnataka Power Transmission Corporation Limited (K P T C L) reports similar challenges. "We are working to optimize distribution and minimize disruption," stated a K P T C L spokesperson. Industry experts warn the situation could worsen in the coming weeks, impacting small businesses and households alike, particularly those reliant on electricity for daily activities like cooking and running water pumps. Residents are advised to conserve energy wherever possible. Reports indicate that the average household power bill could increase by rupees five hundred to eight hundred this month due to increased usage and reliance on backup generators.
